Modern high-speed fighter jets already use similar concepts, deliberately designing the planes on the edge of stability so that they can maneuver with minimal lag and energy output, in exchange for more difficult handling (often computer aided) and higher fuel consumption. But if your goal is to out-maneuver other planes in a dogfight, that is the first priority.

Dang this fish reminds me of the design choice of some fighter jets like the f-16 or Eurofighter. They were designed to be intentionally unstable to be better at manuvering while a computer and  "fly-by-wire" controls would assist the pilot with stability. Honestly a win-win. Smart swimming box.

It shouldn't be such a surprise that it's so manoeuvrable.  It's been known for generations that a ship's turning circle is directly related to its length-width ratio.  Want a fast ship?  Long and narrow.  Want a tight-turning ship?  Short and fat.

So why did the fish evolve to be box-shaped?  Can they avoid predators better than a sleek fish?  Perhaps the box-shape allows it to eat more than a skinny fish?

While the box shape would be something new for fighter aircraft (and a design that probably promptly would end in the trash bin due to radar visibility issues) intentional instability would not. A commercial jet is built for stability, but a fighter jet is mostly intentionally designed to be extremely unstable for the reasons mentioned in the video - for maneuverability. And without computer assistance, they are very hard to fly even for the most experienced pilot.

Cool that evolution "came up" with the same concept, though it shouldn't really be surprising! :)

This is kind of like the forward-swept wing design of some fighter jets. They look like planes with their wings on backwards, and are inherently unstable. But, like the box-fish, those funny-looking wings make these jets more responsive to fast maneuvers, with the trade-off of straight flight needing more fine-tuned computer control. Real Engineering has a great video on the topic

Interestingly, that instability principle is used on fighter jets. Passenger airlines are super stable, and take a long time to turn. Fighter jets need to turn on a dime, and often need computers to help correct minor perturbations the pilot didn’t intend to make.

First the scientists argued "they can maneuver quickly because they're so stable." Then, when they found that they're not stable at all, they argue "they can maneuver quickly because they're so UNstable." So basically, regardless what the actual effect is of their shape, scientists will use it to explain their agility. The real agility here is that of the capricious scientist mind

Much like negatively stable aircraft, such as many fighters or stealth planes. The nighthawk is so unstable that it’s on-board computer makes tens of thousands of corrections to the flight controls each second to keep its trajectory. If it’s computer failed, it would just tumble out of the sky. Helicopters are also negative stability aircraft, which have similar advantages and disadvantages

jet plane engineers have already made intentionally-unstable designs for increased maneuverability. the x-29 was done that way with forward-swept wings, so unstable it required computer assistance to pilot

This is a similar concept used in fighter jets since the 70's.  Most aircraft are stable and will remain pointed in the direction of motion once control when there's no control inputs. Fighter jets since the 70's are unstable and rely on computers to keep the plane flying in the desired direction because the aerodynamics of the plane makes it want to tumble, but also much more maneuverable.

This sounds a lot like unstable-maneuverability in fight jets.  Many modern designs are inherently unstable to take advantage of the enhancement to maneuverability you mention; with computerized 'fly-by-wire' systems handling the minor adjustments to maintain normal flight control.
